attributes.title: Alternatives to Clientelism in Accessing State Services

q1.value: Alternatives to Clientelism in Accessing State Services

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: This experiment includes many descriptive, qualitative and quantitative data that is novel, especially the level of detail on systematic data of clientelistic natures and claim making behavior. The baseline data was used to formulate this pre analysis plan and served as exploratory data. The motivation of the paper is to study how providing services usually provided by clientelistic brokers change citizen behavior and attitudes towards the state.

q16.value: Three main hypotheses are tested: 1. Providing a non-partisan brokerage service will increase the claims individuals make to the state (as measured by the requests done for simple welfare benefits) 2. Providing a non-partisan brokerage service will strengthen citizen's procedural knowledge about the way government distributes welfare benefits. 3. Providing a non-partisan brokerage service will increase citizen's feelings of autonomy of requesting and claiming welfare benefits from the state 4. Providing a non-partisan brokerage service will worsen citizen's evaluations of clientelistic exchanges.

q17.value: I test this through a field experiment in 150 poor localities in the Mexican state of Yucatan. The intervention randomly introduces a community intermediary recruited in 75 of the localities, trained to inform and assist citizens in formally requesting government resources that are usually brokered by partisan intermediaries. A baseline and endline survey will provide individual level outcomes. Administrative data on claims made to the state provides data at the locality level. A large number of supplementary data will be used to analyze mechanisms and uncover clientelistc structures and the ways in which they affect citizen's interaction with the state.

attributes.title: Presidential Candidates and Ad Messaging in the 2016 General Election

q1.value: Presidential Candidates and Ad Messaging in the 2016 General Election

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Observational data to validate experimental results from Carlin and Love (2016). See attached document for full details.

q16.value: H1: Clinton will run significantly more negative ads focused on Trump than positive or mixed ads (contains positive content about Clinton and negative about Trump). H2: Trump’s set of ads will be more balanced between positive (Trump) and negative (Clinton) than Clinton’s ad set. See attached document.

q17.value: Statistical analysis (regression, parametric comparisons (t-test), and non-parametric (Wilcoxon)) of observational data.

registration_responses.q15: Observational data to validate experimental results from Carlin and Love (2016). See attached document for full details.

attributes.title: IGO Endorsements and Support for the REDD+ program

q1.value: IGO Endorsements and Support for the REDD+ program

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: This study presents respondents with a mock newspaper article and asks them to indicate their support for US contributions to a scheme (REDD+) intended to combat destruction of the rainforests. In the study I shall be asking the respondents’ level of support for the proposed contribution while undertaking two separate manipulations: 1. Whether the reader is told that other countries (specifically, Canada and Germany) have contributed to the scheme; and 2. Whether the reader is told that prominent IGOs (specifically, the OECD and World Bank) support this initiative.

q16.value: The hypotheses being tested are as follows: H1: Providing information about Canada and Germany’s contributions to the program will cause respondents to become more supportive of the program. H2: Providing information about endorsements by IGOs will cause respondents to become more supportive of the program. H3: Providing information about endorsements by IGOs will cause left-leaning respondents to become more supportive of the program, but will have the opposite effect on right-leaning respondents. H4: Providing information about the success of other countries’ policies in the context of their status as fellow members of IGOs will lead to an increase in support for the program that is even greater than the effect of either stimulus in isolation.

q17.value: The key dependent variable is support for the proposed contribution of $2bn by the US government to the REDD+ program. This is measured on a 6-point scale. I shall compare the mean score on this 6-point scale across the treatment groups. For H3, I shall (1) interact the level of support with the party identification variable; and (2) interact the level of support with the liberal/conservative scale.

attributes.title: GOTV via SMS: Adopt-a-voter and Calendar Experiment

q1.value: GOTV via SMS: Adopt-a-voter and Calendar Experiment

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: This field experiment examines SMS text messages as a method of voter mobilization. The experiment tests how different variations of text messages sent to registered voters encouraging voting can increase voter turnout in the 2018 midterm elections. Despite widespread use, SMS messages have received little scholarly attention as a medium for campaign communication (Dale and Strauss 2009; Malhotra et al 2011; Bhatti et al 2017b). This experiment is part of a series of experiments in the 2018 general election to build on this prior research. The experiment compares four treatments and a uncontacted control group. The Information treatment relies on positive descriptive norms, civic duty and information about voting to increase turnout. These tactics are very common in voter mobilization and have been successful in past randomized controlled tests (see Green and Gerber 2015 for review). For the Adopt-a-voter treatment, the first message for each method of voting encouraged recipient to get friends and family members to vote (EIPV+EDay series got the Adopt-a-voter message twice). The Adopt-a-Voter treatment was based on leveraging the social rewards from voting (e.g. Sinclair 2012). Delivering similar Adopt-a-Voter treatments by mail has successfully increased in-person voter turnout (e.g. Mann & Klofstad 2011). This treatment generated significant increases in turnout in a prior experiment in 2017. For the Calendar treatment, the second message for each method of voting includes an option to create a reminder to vote in the recipient’s smartphone calendar. The Calendar treatment was based on the “plan-making” mechanism originally investigated as a voter mobilization strategy by Nickerson and Rogers (2010) and now used in an array of voter mobilization experiments that have increased turnout (see Green and Gerber 2015). This treatment also generated significant increases in turnout in a prior experiment in 2017. The Adopt + Calendar treatment includes both the Adopt-a-voter message (1st) and Calendar messages (2nd), along with the informational messages used in all treatments. The experiment is conducted in multiple states covering a range of electoral contexts (defined by competitiveness, voting procedures, and other characteristics). In six states, the treatments were targeted at both early in person voting (EIPV) and Election Day voting (EDay voting): Arizona, Florida, Kansas, Nevada, North Carolina, Tennessee. In five states, the treatments targeted only Election Day voting: Michigan, Mississippi, Montana, Ohio, Vermont. In the states with EIPV and EDay voting, the experiment addresses a secondary research question about mobilization for these two types of in-person voting: is it more effective to mobilize voters to vote early, to vote on Election Day, or to mobilize for early voting and then for Election Day voting? To the best of our knowledge, this question has received almost no attention despite the widespread availability of early in person voting (cf. Mann and Mayhew 2012). Therefore, treatment records in these states are assigned to mobilization for EIPV only (20%), Election Day only (20%), or both (60%)

attributes.title: Cultural Revival and Electoral Politics: Mobilization of Lomwe Ethnic Identity in Malawi

q1.value: Cultural Revival and Electoral Politics: Mobilization of Lomwe Ethnic Identity in Malawi

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Ethnic and tribal identities form the basis of political organization in many Sub-Saharan African countries, where ethnic affiliations are strongly correlated with vote choice, partisanship, policy preferences, provision of government services, and allegiances during civil conflict. Despite a common portrayal of African politics as being inherently mired by tribal animosities, most scholars of African politics attribute the centrality of ethnicity in politics to elite level political competition for political support. In fact, there is ample historical evidence that many contemporary ethnic identities were constructed or shaped from the top-down by political elites. However, because most of this research has focused on elite incentives and behavior, we know very little about when and why ethnic appeals resonate with citizens, how ethnic mobilization translates into political support, or what the implications of such political mobilization are for cultural change. This research project addresses these important questions in the context of a contemporary case of ethnic political mobilization currently underway in Malawi. In particular, the Lhomwe ethnic group – a historically stigmatized and politically marginalized group – has very recently been mobilized on the basis of their ethnicity by political elites. This mobilization has been spearheaded by a new ethnic association – Mulhako wa Alhomwe – established in 2008, and a new political party – the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) – created in 2005. Because the mobilization of the Lhomwe population is quite recent and ongoing, it offers a unique opportunity to address fundamental open questions about the process of ethnic mobilization as it evolves, and to collect the attitudes, motivations, and behaviors of those involved. The research design combines elite interviews, oral histories, and an original survey. The survey will have two embedded experiments, and the timing of the survey will be varied in relation to the annual Lhomwe cultural gathering.

q16.value: The research addresses 4 central questions. (1) How, why, and among whom has mobilization of the Lhomwe ethnic identity translated into political support for the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP)? (2) Is the Lhomwe political mobilization changing cultural practices among ordinary people, and, if so, through what mechanisms? (3) How are Lhomwe ethnic boundaries being defined and defended in response to the group's rising political influence? (4) What is the role of the ethnic association, Mulhako wa Alhomwe, in political mobilization, cultural change, and defining Lhomwe identity?

q17.value: I will evaluate the relationship between cultural attributes (ethnic identity salience, strength of identification, and sub-group identity ) and political attitudes and behavior (electoral support and assessment of government) using both observational and experimental methods. First, I will field an original survey targeted at members of the Lhomwe ethnic group within Malawi. Within the context of the survey, I will use a question ordering to prime either ethnicity or politics, and compare responses across order sets. The survey also includes an endorsement experiment to measure support for key political and ethnic actors. Finally, the survey timing will be randomly varied with respect to an annual gathering of Lhomwe during which the salience of the identity is expected to be especially strong. Second, I will document changes over time through the use of in-depth oral histories with elderly members of the Lhomwe ethnic group. Third, I will interview relevant elite actors, including Mulhako wa Alhomwe leadership, DPP officials and politicians, Lhomwe traditional authorities, and leaders of other ethnic associations.

q19.value: 1260 survey respondents across 36 enumeration areas, 36 oral history respondents, 10-15 elite interviewees

q24.value: Ohio State University ( 2016B0201 ), Malawi National Commission for Science and Technology (P.08/16/128 )

registration_responses.q1: Cultural Revival and Electoral Politics: Mobilization of Lomwe Ethnic Identity in Malawi
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to any research activities

(2) Is the Lhomwe political mobilization changing cultural practices among ordinary people, and, if so, through what mechanisms? registration_responses.q19: 1260 survey respondents across 36 enumeration areas, 36 oral history respondents, 10-15 elite interviewees
registration_responses.q24: Ohio State University ( 2016B0201 ), Malawi National Commission for Science and Technology (P.08/16/128 )

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: The purpose of this research is to run a laboratory experiment that tests the psychological effect of institutional format on individual behavior. Specifically, we are interested in the degree to which presidential systems and parliamentary systems incentivize divergent behavior among actors. There is a long-standing debate about the pros and cons of presidentialism vs parliamentarism. However, the empirical evidence in support of either position in relation to the impact on democracy is contradictory. The debate remains unsettled in this regard. This empirical work is based on theoretical arguments about the psychological effects of presidentialism and parliamentarism. Yet, these effects have not been tested. Specifically, arguments originating with Juan Linz suggest that presidentialism provides fewer behavioral incentives for actors to compromise than parliamentarism. We wish to test this psychological mechanism. If we find no evidence for the psychological mechanism at play, this may explain why the empirical results have been contradictory. If we do find evidence, it suggests we should continue with empirical inquiry on this topic.

q16.value: We expect actors in a presidential system to be more likely to behave less responsively to the parties in the legislature. We expect this institutional effect to be mediated by the party system and the level of presidential power. All else equal, when the president has more constitutional powers, the president will be less likely to work with the legislature. When there is a two-party system, the president will be less likely to work with the legislature. We have four theoretical expectations: 1.) When there is a two-party system and the president has few powers, we would expect greater conflict between the president and her own party relative to prime ministers and their own party. 2.) When there is a two-party system and the president has high powers, we expect presidents and prime ministers to behave similarly, dominating their party 3.) When there is a multi-party system and the president has few powers, we expect the president to cooperate with the legislature in a similar manner to prime ministers - coalitional presidentialism 4.) When there is a multi-party system and the president has high powers, we expect greater conflict between president and all other parties relative to prime ministers and other parties

q17.value: We are adopting a ‘perspective-taking’ experimental approach. We ask participants in the lab to take a certain perspective and to observe their reactions when faced with different scenarios. We ask participants to take the perspective of an executive (not specifying whether it is presidential or parliamentary) and then measure their propensity to cooperate with their own party and with parties in the legislature, given a variety of scenarios that reflect different party systems and executive power. For the control group, these scenarios occur as if in a parliamentary system; for the treatment group, they occur as if in a presidential system. We ask participants to complete a series of questions asking them whether they will compromise with or oppose the legislature and their own party, given the condition and treatment they were exposed to. In this way, we can get at the main causal effect of interest: the psychological effect of executive office and the conditioning effect of other variables.

q27.value: Centre for Experimental Social Sciences (CESS) Nuffield College, University of Oxford

attributes.title: Public and Private Voting Behavior in Uganda

q1.value: Public and Private Voting Behavior in Uganda

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: In this pre-analysis plan I describe how I will test my theory of dependency-driven voting and investigate whether a social norm of voting exists in Uganda. Using a lab-in-the-field experiment conducted in collaboration with MIT GOV/LAB and Twaweza, an NGO in East Africa, I examine how Ugandan citizens in Central and Northern regions evaluate hypothetical MP candidates in a conjoint experiment and analyze their decision to incur a financial cost to vote in these hypothetical elections. This plan was written after data collection but prior to data analysis.

q16.value: I will compare public and private voting behavior in an experimental context to assess whether citizens are motivated to vote, when it comes at a financial cost, in order to comply with a social norm of voting.

q17.value: By randomly assigning respondents to a public and private condition where voting behavior is either in the presence of peers or in secret I will observe whether the presence of peers increases an individual's probability of voting in the experiment.

registration_responses.q1: Public and Private Voting Behavior in Uganda
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

attributes.title: IGO Endorsements and Support for a Gasoline Tax

q1.value: IGO Endorsements and Support for a Gasoline Tax

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: This study presents respondents with a mock newspaper article and asks them to indicate their support for a proposed gasoline tax. The article explains that the gas tax is intended as a means to mitigate global warming. In the study I shall be asking the respondents’ level of support for the proposed tax while undertaking three distinct manipulations: 1. Whether the reader is told that other countries (specifically, Canada and Germany) have successfully implemented carbon pricing schemes; 2. Whether the reader is told that prominent IGOs (specifically, the OECD and World Bank) support this initiative; and 3. Whether the reader is primed with with the example of the United Nations when asked a question about his or her support for interventions by international organizations in various issue areas.

q16.value: H1: Providing information about the success of Canada and Germany’s carbon-pricing policies will make respondents more supportive of the gas tax. H2: Providing information about endorsements by IGOs will cause respondents to be generally more supportive of the gas tax. H3: Providing information about endorsements by IGOs will cause left-leaning respondents to become more supportive of the gas tax, but will have the opposite effect on right-leaning respondents. H4: Providing information about the success of other countries’ policies in the context of their status as fellow members of IGOs will lead to an increase in support for the gas tax that is even greater than the effect of either stimulus in isolation. H5: Citing the United Nations as an example of an IGO will cause respondents to favor a smaller role for IGOs in international affairs.

Whether the reader is primed with with the example of the United Nations when asked a question about his or her support for interventions by international organizations in various issue areas.
registration_responses.q16: H1: Providing information about the success of Canada and Germany’s carbon-pricing policies will make respondents more supportive of the gas tax. H2: Providing information about endorsements by IGOs will cause respondents to be generally more supportive of the gas tax. H3: Providing information about endorsements by IGOs will cause left-leaning respondents to become more supportive of the gas tax, but will have the opposite effect on right-leaning respondents. H4: Providing information about the success of other countries’ policies in the context of their status as fellow members of IGOs will lead to an increase in support for the gas tax that is even greater than the effect of either stimulus in isolation. H5: Citing the United Nations as an example of an IGO will cause respondents to favor a smaller role for IGOs in international affairs.

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Terrorism presents a fundamental paradox – terrorist groups are vastly weaker in terms of their capacity to inflict harm than the government they oppose, yet they often receive a tremendous amount of attention from the state, as the above examples demonstrate. In other words, per a traditional strategic logic, for powerful states, terrorism should generally rank as a minor concern meriting only limited diplomatic engagement or military retaliation; the capacity of terrorists to hurt is simply not high enough (Schelling 1966). However, powerful governments often do engage in costly reactions in the face of terrorist threats, either in the form of concessions or, more often, expensive military engagements. What are the factors that lead these governments to react so strongly against terrorist groups that appear to pose little to no existential threat to the state? Do the tactical target choices of terrorist groups play a role in triggering these expansive vs. limited state reactions? This project argues that, indeed, terrorists’ tactical choices surrounding target selection are crucial to understanding the strategic logic of terrorism. Existing strategic models of terrorism are incomplete due because they do not disaggregate the targets of terrorist violence and consider the psychological impact of specific attack strategies on civilian populations’ perceptions of personal threat and risk. Specifically, this research contends that terrorism seeks to attrit or provoke powerful states through a purposeful strategic psychology that is designed to capitalize on psychological biases in risk assessment and divergent preferences between governments and their citizens. Namely, because the state’s citizens care more about who was attacked rather than how difficult it was to attack them, governments are more likely to engage in stronger, costlier counter-terrorism efforts in the wake of attacks on soft, civilian targets than following attacks on harder military or governmental targets of the same magnitude.

q16.value: 1) H1: Citizens will be more likely to overestimate the risk to their personal safety and report higher threat levels from terrorism after exposure to attacks against the mass public than after attacks against the government. 2) H2: Citizens will be more likely to view terrorists as immoral and illegitimate following attacks on the mass public than following attacks against the government. 3) H3: Citizens will be more likely to support costlier government responses to terror attacks and be less supportive of maintaining status quo policies following attacks on the mass public than following attacks against the government. 4) H4: Citizens will reduce their electoral support for political leaders that do not follow their policy preferences. 5) H5: Citizens will express significantly higher levels of anger and fear, threat perceptions, negative moral judgments, and costly policy support in the mass public conditions, regardless of fortification type. However, when comparing soft target threats to hard target threats (collapsing across target type), the difference in citizens’ responses will be much smaller. 6) H6: Anger, as a risk-taking approach emotion, will lead to support for more aggressive policies, while fear, as a risk-avoidant aversive emotion, may lead to support for more conciliatory or isolationist policies. Both types of policies are potentially ‘costly,’ but on different dimensions.

q17.value: The main analysis will compare the psychological and political responses of those in the mass public conditions to those in the government conditions. The basic model is as follows: Yi = ∝+ β1 (Ti )+β2 (Xi )+ εi Yi denotes the outcome variable of interest – emotions, threat perceptions, policy preferences and leader support. β1 (Ti ) denotes the estimate of the average treatment effect. β2 (Xi ) is a vector of covariates that exhibited significant imbalance in the pre-testing phase between treatment and control groups at baseline. ∝ is the effect of the omitted condition. εi is the error term.

registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to assignment of treatment
